title: Tesla’s third-quarter sales seen on the rise
text:
Tesla Inc. is expected to report rising quarterly vehicle sales in the next few days, but don’t expect that to move the needle for the stock.

Some analysts see a better-than-expected sales period for Tesla TSLA, +6.06%, but sentiment on the stock continues to be lukewarm on concerns that the company’s sales targets for the year are unattainable.

Tesla is likely to report third-quarter production and delivery numbers, the latter its proxy for sales, in early October, or a few days after the end of the quarter. Unlike some car makers that report monthly sales and break them down by region and other variables, it reports the numbers per vehicle model.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect the company to have sold 98,000 vehicles in the third quarter, including 79,600 Model 3 sedans. Sales of its luxury Model S sedan and Model X SUV are seen at evenly split at 8,600 units each Model.

That would compare with 84,000 vehicles in the third quarter of 2018, which included about 56,000 Model 3s.

Analysts at RBC Capital Markets raised their third-quarter delivery expectations to 97,200 vehicles, from a prior forecast of 86,300 vehicles.

“Europe looks to be coming in stronger, particularly the Netherlands” with launch of a right-hand traffic Model 3 in the U.K., the analysts, led by Joseph Spak, said in a note Thursday. Anything slightly under 100,000 would be “well received” by the market, the analysts said.



“Like last quarter, we are more focused on the 3Q19 financial report which may again show tension between volume and profit,” they said.

See also: Tesla Model 3 earns top safety award from insurance group

Analysts at Wedbush were less sanguine about Tesla’s hitting sales expectations.

“Based on the US demand and improved European trajectory, coupled by pockets of weakness in China, we believe Tesla will come up shy of Street expectations with an (88,000 to 90,000) range more likely,” they said.

“While unit numbers will be the ultimate driver of the stock in our opinion and have seen an encouraging rebound over the past two quarters from the 1Q debacle, Tesla has also continued to initiate cost cutting measures to help drive sustained profitability to the bottom line which is a positive move that investors are laser focused on,” they said.

The “biggest overhang” for Tesla is the 2019 sales guidance, the Wedbush analysts said. That’s “going to be a Herculean-like task in our opinion as (the range of about 345,000 to 350,000 vehicles sold) is likely the line in the sand as Street whisper numbers have continued to come down over the past few months,” the Wedbush analysts, led by Dan Ives, said.

Related: Beyond Meat poaches Tesla’s head of solar to be new operating chief

If Tesla is able to sell 280,000 Model 3 sedans this year, that would be a success “and ultimately put the company on more stable ground heading into 2020,” the analysts said.

Tesla has said it expects to deliver between 360,000 and 400,000 vehicles in all of 2019. The analysts polled by FactSet expect sales of 358,000 for the year.

The 33 analysts on FactSet on average rate Tesla shares at neutral, and the average price target on the stock is $270, which would represent an upside of nearly 18% on Thursday’s price.

Tesla is expected to report third-quarter results in early November, and the analysts surveyed by FactSet expect the company to show an adjusted loss of 42 cents a share on sales of $6.4 billion. That would contrast with an adjusted profit of $2.90 a share on sales of $6.8 billion in the year-ago period.

Read more: Tesla launches its car insurance in California

Tesla shares have lost 31% this year, contrasting with gains of 19% and 15% for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.24% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average. DJIA, -0.30%
description: Tesla Inc. likely will report rising quarterly vehicle sales in the next few days, but don’t expect that to move the needle for the stock.
